In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

In Julia, you can define the `clean_column` function within a module to make it more reusable:

```julia
module CleanColumnDriver

export clean_column

function clean_column(col::String)
    # Lowercase the column name
    col = lowercase(col)
    # Strip leading and trailing whitespaces
    col = strip(col)
    # Replace spaces and hyphens with underscores
    col = replace(col, r"\s|-" => "_")
    return col
end

end # module CleanColumnDriver
```

Now you can use `clean_column` in your code by first requiring the module:

```julia
julia> using .CleanColumnDriver

julia> clean_column("My Column") == "my_column"
true
```

The `strip` function removes leading and trailing whitespace, but not whitespace between words. The regular expression used in `replace` will match both spaces (`"\s"`) and hyphens (`"-"`), ensuring that they are replaced with underscores (`"_"`).
